newsitem.title: JAPAN: FORECAST - Japan Apr output seen rising slightly.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Japan Apr output seen rising slightly.

text.p: Japan's industrial output for April is expected to be flat or slightly higher than March, remaining firm as the effects of the April 1 tax rise would not yet to be reflected, economists said on Thursday.
Economists polled by Reuters forecast rises ranging from 0.3 percent to 1.5 percent in April output, compared with a month-on-month drop of 0.3 percent in March.
The Trade Ministry expects major manufacturers' output to show a 0.3 percent rise in April.
Industrial output data for April and forecasts for May and June will be released on May 29 at 1.30 p.m. (0430 GMT).

"The (output) figure will show that production continues to be firm. There are some left-over orders for car production from the period before the tax rise, so that will give support," said Osamu Katano, an economist at Nikko Research Center.
Japan raised its national consumption tax to five percent from three percent on April 1, and consumption is widely expected to have dropped following the move.
But economists also said the weak yen led to strong exports and supported production.

"In April, the yen was still relatively weak and exports were strong. All in all, production is firm so we can expect it to be flat for April," said Yasuo Yamamoto, an economist with Sanwa Research Institute.
An economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell also said strong car exports in April lifted production.
But economists said the outlook for production may not be as rosy as the tax rise begins to take its toll.
"From May onward, there may be a decrease in production due to the effects of the rise in the consumption tax," said Nikko Research's Katano.
